Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: The ambulance driver is moving the vehicle from the main station to a satellite location for a shift change.
Story: I gripped the steering wheel of the ambulance, my mind half on the road, half on my phone buzzing in the cup holder. My little brother’s text flashed on the screen: “About to try the new trick. Wish me luck!” I pictured him, helmet askew, grinning at the top of that cracked, steep ramp behind our house. As his sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But right now, I was on duty, expected to drive the ambulance safely to the satellite station for the shift change. I couldn’t just pull over or speed up to get there faster. My supervisor had drilled it into us—no distractions, no rushing, no exceptions. But my brother’s safety gnawed at me. What if he fell? What if he needed help and I wasn’t there? My hands tightened on the wheel, torn between the urge to call him, to warn him, and the responsibility to keep the ambulance steady and safe. The city blurred past, and my heart pounded, caught between the flashing lights of duty and the tug of family.
